_exec_summary.SummaryText:
nt History:
There has not been a release of anhydrous ammonia from this facility in the previous five years that has caused death, injuries, or, significant property damage, nor that has had any off-site consequences.

Emergency Response Program:
This facility is included in the written Community Emergency Response Plan as prepared by the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Nebraska Emergency Management Agency (NEMA). We also include these materials in our own Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38. We have provided state and local authorities all Community Right-to-Know information requested as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA). Our written employee safety programs include pre emergency planning and employee training in accordance with OSHA standards, and are offered for review at any time by our LEPC to ensure they conform to the community plan(s). We actively encourage local emergency responder participation in our anhydrous ammonia training programs so they may be aware of what might be expected if responding to an incident at our site.

Planned Changes to Safety:
Safety improvement is an ongoing process at all of our facilities. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific recommendations for implementation at this time.

For additional information, contact:

Phone: 402-469-6452

ble public and environmental receptors within the area, have been provided to the County Local Emergency Planning Committee to assist them with their planning efforts.

Alternative Case Release Scenario:
We believe the most likely release would be caused by a leaky valve. Valves are protected by self-closing excess flow valves so our alternative release scenario is based on the loss of contents from the largest hose used for application equipment. The distance to endpoint is determined by EPA’s RMP Comp Program.

Accidental Release Program:
Our Anhydrous Ammonia accidental release program is based on guidelines found in  the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) standard K61.1-1989 “Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia” and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standard 29 CFR 1910.111 “Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia”. We conduct annual employee training on the safe handling, transportation and distribution of anhydrous ammonia and have installed safety equipment, including, but not limited to: excess flow valves, breakaway couplers at risers, emergency shutoff valves, collision protection barriers, and locks to limit unauthorized access to product. We also maintain routine contact with our local emergency responders and encourage and participate in training related to anhydrous ammonia. Our company has an Emergency Action Plan for employee, customer, and visitor protection in the event of fire, explosion, tornado, or other incident that may require evacuation and/or emergency medical care. Emergency contact information is included in the plan, as well as evacuation routes and assembly points. The primary emergency coordinator is listed in the Registration Section of this document. Any of the following additional individuals may be contacted in the event the primary emergency coordinator cannot be reached:

Five Year Accide

Company Name: Cooperative Producers Inc.
Facility Name: Fairmont Nurse Tank Farm
Mailing Address: 2014 Road 12, FAIRMONT, NE. 68354

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

Facility Policy:
The management and employees operating at each of our facilities are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of hazardous materials transported or stored at our locations. In the event an accidental release should occur, we are prepared to work with our local emergency response personnel and other appropriate authorities to best mitigate the incident and minimize the impact of the release to the public and the environment.

Facility Information:
The primary activity of our company is NAICS Code 115111, “Support Activity for Crop Production”. We provide agricultural inputs for crop production that include storing anhydrous ammonia for delivery to farmers in our area.

Anhydrous ammonia is stored and distributed for direct application to farm fields during the spring and fall of the year. During the balance of the year there is minimal product transfer occurring. The maximum quantity handled at a given time would be one nurse tank with a maximum capacity of 900 gallons.

The facility is operated on an “as needed” basis with staff present only during receiving and product delivery. Total annual hours for these needs do not meet the 2080 hour requirement to qualify as a “full time employee” on site, therefore item number 1.11 is “Zero”. Our facilities have adequate lighting and are inspected at various times during the day and night. Time spent on these inspections is not calculated in our staffing hours.

Worst Case Release Scenario:
The worst case release scenario is considered to be the release of the total contents of our largest anhydrous ammonia nurse tank.
